reviewText:
Randomness, randomness and more randomness.  I felt while playing this game that I wasn't so much actually PLAYING the game as just sharing the Orion Trail experience, because from beginning to end, the game is basically pure luck.  You choose from random sets of crewmen presented to you, to give you certain stats, and that's about all you do to influence how the session goes.  I mean, you can pick your path in which systems to move towards, and whether or not to stop at certain things, I suppose, but it's not much of a choice, because in any given thing, you have no real control over your consequences.

There are no upgrades to purchase to make you more likely to succeed.  Your crew's stats can go up or down at a whim, as random events between nodes tick these abilities up or down with no input from you.  The time honored tradition of visiting tombstones from previous playthroughs on games like Oregon Trail is doable here, but even doing THIS can cause an utterly random stat raise or decrease.  Even what skills you use during a particular incident is entirely random most of the time;  You can push up and specialize in a particular stat only to be presented with an event that doesn't allow you to use that stat.  Even the -rewards or penalties- can be randomized in many events.

Perhaps in some games, all of this randomness wouldn't be a problem.  Orion Trail tries to allieviate things a bit with its quirky and outlandish dialogue, and it works for a time.  However, said dialogue runs out too quickly, frequently recycled every playthrough.  Given you need to play through the game multiple times to unlock the content... this is a rather serious thing.  Also not present is any sense of fairness.  On any given random event, no matter how good you are in the stat, you have the chance to critically fail, and the critical failure events are so harsh that just one of them can completely break your run, often completely exhausting a vital resource.  Critical successes, on the other hand, while certainly nice, do not give you things on quite the same scale.  Furthermore, it's almost impossible to recover from a critical failure because your rewards are often given randomly as well, and you can't just complete events that'll raise the thing the Critical Failure took from you, because the opportunities are just not given.

All and all, I'd go as far to say that the game is 100% Pure Luck in whether you succeed or not, and there's not enough dialogue in the game to make playing such a ludicrously random game worth your while.  Stick to FTL for your starship piloting dreams.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played this game for 28 minutes. Enough time for two run-throughs. Time-wise, that was exactly what I was looking for in a game like this. I loved Organ Trail, even though I've only played it for 7 hours or so. I really enjoyed that game and was looking for something similar. This game was not it.

The problem with this game is it feels like soul-less RNG. There are no interesting decisions. Even picking your crew, you need to specialize to get the highest number possible in one category or another, meaning choosing a captain with a skill of 3, and a crew member with a skill of 2, with as much overlap in the same skill as possible, is a no-brainer. Combat basically amounts to rolling a die. Nothing you do can manipulate those odds. Planet exploration is the only interesting part of the game, but just barely. It amounts to a simple press your luck" decision game. You can choose the path your spaceship takes
date: like sometimes... but the only decision there is to go to which resource you need most. And if the resource on both ends of the branch is the same
recommended: is that really much of a decision? You have no idea what sort of RNG event is going to happen or affect it in any way
voteText: Organ Trail had lots of action-RPG events where you get rewarded for skillful gameplay and are constantly making decisions that affect your success.\n\nIn the end
helpfulPercent: this game plays itself. You're just there to watch and click buttons when necessary. No strategy. No tactics. Nothing. Really wanted to like this game. Didn't."

reviewText: Game was going alright so far.  Had a great run going, 3/4 of the way through then BAM, one bad roll and the enter run was deleted.  I want to like this game so very much, but the amount of punishment on the negative rolls is huge compared to the reward.  Also the inability to anything to change the gameplay besides stack the odds as best you can leaves me feeling very powerless to do much as a player other than click through the menus and hope for the best.  As it currently stands, I can't really recommend the game unless someone is looking to while away a couple of hours doing something else and listening to the nice soundtrack while clicking around the game and enjoying the very good pixel art.\n\nIf the gameplay was as good as the art and soundtrack, I'd easily give this game 10/10.  As it currently stands though, the gameplay is lacking and the dice rolls are too punishing to even let this be an enjoyable distraction.  The game is trying to be difficult like oregon trail, but it doesn't reward the player for doing anything right.  This means the only thing you can do as a player is min/max and hope for the best.  If that appeals to you, click away, but I need some more reward for spending time with the game and learning the system.  Therefore I can't recommend the game in it's current state.

reviewText: I'm glad I bought this game on sale, because I've seen everything it had to offer right at the two-hour mark aside from some crew members; I've played through all the galaxies in three-and-a-half hours. In fact, all the events repeat very often.\nGood animations, but unfortunately they're constrained to a tiny window at the bottom of the screen. There were some funny moments, but they don't stay funny after the first time you've seen them. Get ready to feel burnt out on reading.\nMaybe if they flesh out the game in the future I'll change my opinion, but just not feeling it's worth the money at this time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never thought I'd write a review about a game complaining about its RNG... I was wrong.

The game takes the Oregon Trail formula and adds a hilarious sci-fi theme over top. That's about the only positive thing I can say about the game.

Your choices don't matter. You just tell the game which adventure you choose and it rolls the dice. The only strategy involved is trying to stack a certain stat to make the dice rolls more favorable.

I would fail more often than not, even with the odds ridiculously stacked in my favor. I'm not sure if RNGesus has just forsaken me or if their random numbers aren't really that random.

This game has an amusing concept, but as a game it's boring and frustrating.

reviewText:
THERE ARE FOUR LIGHTS!

Think of it as a choose your own adventure novel filled with nods to the sci fi genre.  Each point in space offers multiple ways of handling the situation.  Each way can result in 4 different narrative paths.  The situations repeat often.  Choosing different options and having the RNG spit out different results will keep repeating stories fresh.  I often found myself speeding through dialog I'd seen before until I branched into a new result.

You choose your crew who each have a few points toward 5 different attributes.  These attributes give you a better chance at getting a positive result in the RNG.  Focusing on 2 of the 5 attributes seems to work well.

There is some resource management.  It boils down to Hey
date:
we're low on fuel.  Let's choose the get fuel option."

The humor is stupendous.  The music and sound effects are charming.

If you're looking for a low brain power time waster

votesHelpful: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is quite cool, even if I'm not a big fan of RNG driven games. You select your crew at the start of the missions and this sets your strengths and weaknesses. During the game you'll encounter various obstacles and you can overcome them by choosing from three options out of five attributes. The higher the attribute the better the chance that you'll pass the encounter successfully. You have to manage resources and during the missions there are ways to exchange one of the four for another. I think those aspects make the game feel less RNG based and more like you actually have (some) influence on the outcome.

The presentation is simple, but fits the game very well. The pixel graphics have their own style and the UI does have a Star Trek feel to it. The music is decent and sounds a bit like a 60s sci-fi soundtrack on an 8 bit machine.

There is some humour in the game, but it's not a comedy/parody game. It does have a lot of references to old sci-fi, but it doesn't rely on them. The story fragments are well written and there seem to be a lot of them.

Surprisingly interesting build-your-own-adventure/RNG game that will make me come back for more. Everybody that likes this kind of games and/or old sci-fi should have a look for 10 bucks, but everybody else should also give this a try once it goes on sale.
voteText: 16 of 19 people (84%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I backed this game's Kickstarter.  I liked the idea.  It sounded fun.  I can't get past the second level.

This game is 100% random chance.  It feels like no matter what I do, how I arrange my stats, what decisions I make, every last damn encounter is a coin toss.  There's only so many times I can roll a critical fail when I'm supposed to have a 10-in-12 chance of success.  ESPECIALLY when the penalty of that fail is LOWERING THE STAT THAT WAS SUPPOSED TO BE HELPING ME.

I also love it when the game randomly decides to reduce a stat for no reason.

You're presented with numerous choices in this game, all related to little amusing scenarios that pop up at every stop point on the map.  Each option has a different risk/reward, but since each choice is directly affected by one of your stats, you're really just choosing your odds of success.  Why yes game, I WOULD like some more crew, but my science stat is ONE.  Since I KNOW that you'll just kill my crew instead should I fail, I think I'll use my 6 deplomacy for this food I don't need.

Then I fail the roll anyways.  It just really, REALLY feels like the choices are arbitrary.  Maybe they aren't, but that didn't stop it from not being fun for me.  Hell, I quit reading the little stories and just clicked the number when it popped up.  They have no long-term effects, and there’s no over-arching plot to pay attention to.  There’s no reason to care about what’s doing what; the description of the actions have nothing to do with the outcome, just the stat.

Example: I was having a pretty terrible run, but it LOOKED like I could limp to the finish of level 2, but when I was ONE dot away from the end, the game informed me that someone had left the gas cap off, and the last of my fuel fell out.  I proceeded to sit there, inches from the finish line, as my crew literally starved to death waiting for rescue.

To my knowledge, there is nothing I could have done to reduce the odds of my crew being a bunch of morons.

The bottom line is that there is not one, SINGLE action I can take in this game that makes me feel like I have direct control over ANYTHING.  I don’t even feel like there’s a strategy to improve my odds.  They even added the ability to boost your resources at the start of the level, but I have no idea which ones are going to be most drained by the random encounters, so I can’t make any kind of meaningful decision!

Maybe some people find that... exciting, or something.  It just makes me want to pull my hair out.

reviewText:
First, let me admit that I haven't spent hours and hours playing this game; rather, only four playthroughs so far. Nevertheless, I must also point out that I had full faith in this game and Kickstarted it months ago. I'm afraid that faith has taken a hit at this point that I hope the development team will see fit to remedy with future patches.

The Good:
- The art design is delightfully nostalgic and colorful, evocative in the whimsical, retro ways I hoped it would be.
- The writing is ribald tongue-in-cheek, with geek references a-plenty. It manages to be corny fun without being overwrought.

The Bad:
- I sporadically get stuck in Options and the UI becomes unresponsive to clicks, forcing me to quit the game entirely and start over.
- There is no obvious option to select a different batch of captains or officers without restarting the whole process.
- The post-luck is PUNISHING and pre-luck does not seem well-leveraged unless the player leans heavily in one attribute over another. I realize it's all RNG, but I feel remarkably unlucky.
- Furthermore, even I do rely heavily on one or two stats (getting 'lucky' with the random batch of captains and officers offered), the random occurrences seem to target them mercilessly. Twice I've had a captain end up all zeroes at one during their 'trek' to the goal. That shouldn't be possible. I realize that part of the fun is the risk and reward, but my preparations often seem to amount to a hill o' beans and that certainly was not fun.

I ended up quitting out of the game. The game has a lot of potential, but I, for one, would like to request more control of my fate.

EDIT: Came back for three more games after the patch. Still not enjoying myself.

reviewText:
A lot of the reviews on here made legitimate points, but desperately need to be updated.

For instance, the current most helpful rated review complains that there are no upgrades. That has already been addressed and changed; you can now stop at trade hubs and trade for supplies, for upgrades, or rest to regain some HP (but at the expense of losing some food - nothing comes free!).

Other updates include changing up the difficulty a bit. Now when you're on the trail, you can see the difficulty of each point, ranging from one to three skulls. Plus the trail gets progressively more difficult as you reach the end. So there's some added variation in the gameplay now.

Another thing they've added since the early access days is that when you start your mission, you can now spend credits to stock up on fuel, food, crew, or hull points.

I was a backer for this game and have been playing it since the day it came out. I initially wrote a negative review, but I have been consistently impressed and pleased with the updates and how responsive the makers are. This is one of the few games I own that I genuinely think is worth purchasing at full price.

reviewText:
This game is a riot.  I was unsure about it at first due to the early negative reviews, but some of the more recent positive ones indicate that the developers are taking public criticism and suggestions to heart and improving the game.  So, I decided to buy it and I'm sure glad I did.

The game is very Oregon Trail meets Star Trek, minus the educational aspects OT and with lots of humor that (at times) pokes fun at ST.  Basically, you fly through space as the captain of a ship, exploring the galaxy and encountering lots of interesting challenges.  Unlike some space games that are mostly combat, Orion Trail is more of an adventure game and the challenges you face can be anything from problems with your ship and crew to encounters with other ships and space born life to planets that need exploring.  The randomness and variety of encounters and ways you can try to deal with them add to the fun and replay value.  The writing is very clever and funny and is full of hilarious Sci Fi inspired things.  There are a few typos, but nothing too bad.

The game play itself is pretty simple, though it can be at times frustrating and requires a bit of strategy (and luck.)  Encounters offer a set of solutions that use your crew skills, the success of which relies on a roll of the dice
date:
so to speak.  Though, if you use skills that your crew has in abundance, your chance of success is greater, though still not guaranteed.  Apart from crew skills, you rely greatly on resources.  Hull plating to make your ship less susceptible to damage, food for your crew to eat, fuel for your ship's engines and red shirts to sacrifice themselves in various ways, ensuring the survival of your officers.  Successful encounters can reward you with resources or boost your officers' skills, though unsuccessful ones can have the opposite effect.

The graphics, sound and music are all well done and very retro.  Basically, the game looks and feels like an old DOS space game.  Much of the game's style is derived from Star Trek, though it's not an exact copy.  It would be more fair to call it a homage to Star Trek.  It's very resource light and will run on even slow computers.  I was able to run it on my 1 GHz dual core laptop with a so-so GPU and only 3 GB RAM with no issues whatsoever.

So, bottom line, this is a great indie game that doesn't take itself too seriously, nor should you take it too seriously.  It's fun, though at times it seems a bit unfair.  But, hey, that's how life is.
helpfulPercent: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Orion Trail is a combination of clever graphics, rudimentary sound effects, and overwhelmingly random conflict resolution.

While the pixel art and flavor text are definite high points, I find myself put off by my absolute helplessness in the face of the overwhelming power of the probability matrix.  As a consequence, I don't feel like I'm playing this game; the dice are playing this game, and I am watching.

Maybe a gambler would enjoy this game, but I prefer games I can play, not games that play me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a backer, I am impressed by how quickly this game was released into early access. It has a good vibe to it.

The graphics are cute, particularly the Warp Weasel. The writing is clever, and the music is fitting.

There is currently no tutorial but the game play is fairly intuitive. However, if a tutorial level was added, it should be short and touch on the very basic aspects, with minimal interference in gameplay.

I know some people don't see this as a variant on Oregon Trail but the more Schell develops this, the closer the vibe gets to the spirit of Oregon Trail. The variety and options in how you approach each event is great. The outcomes aren't predictable unless you've built your team well.

What I like most is I can pick it up, play for a few minutes and go play something else. This game is great for a few minues or if you just want to go for a while.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I backed this on Kickstarter.

It had a rocky start, but I think it's actually turning out pretty rad. The initial release on Steam had its balance too out of whack, and I can see how that would've frustrated a lot of people.

They've done much to fix this, though, and it's now a genuinely enjoyable coffee break game. I wish we had more of those as inventive, clever, and funny as this.

This is about the best you're going to get when it comes to a retooling of the Oregon Trail game. I was a fan of that game way back when, and I love this even more. Honestly, it's the best of the crop of the games trying to ape it. And the balance, fun, and replayability is far better than Organ Trail.

Plus! It's a great parody for Sci-Fi fans. Especially Star Trek fans. There's a lot of in-jokes there that only they might get. Something to keep in mind. Definitely a bonus for Trek fans, but perhaps a detriment to those who aren't.

Also. You can be a bear. Your captain can be a chubby bear, and they're usually pretty great captains, too. Honestly, what more could you ask for?

If you're an older gamer (like me), you like sci-fi, and you're looking for a short game to pass the time or something like the Oregon Trail, this'll do you.

I admit, this isn't the highest praise. But it is fun, good at what it tries to do, and very much worth the money. This isn't Undertale or the Beginner's Guide, after all. It's like writing a review for Tetris. If you meet the prerequisites I've mentioned, then you're likely to have a really good time.

I recommend it. Quite a bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have left the original review below. As the game has now been released, this is what I now think of it:

It's really good!

All the extra content added since I last played it (life has been busy, so over a month ago!) really shows. The game is far better balanced, more polished, and it feels complete. The devs are still on top of things, making changes based on feedback, which is an extra point in my book. I am especially loving the added random encounters, which really add flavour to the game.

If you're looking for a funny, entertaining, space homage to Oregon Trail, this is your game. It is punishing at times, with a heavy RNG component, but your strategy will make a difference, and it is a hell of a lot of fun to play.


------------------------
At the moment this game is in early access, and it doesn't have as much content as it eventually will, but I still really like it, and I think it has great potential.

I was a Kickstarter backer, as I loved the concept, and so far it has stayed true to it. I really like the art style and the writing. The random encounters are witty and full of sci-fi references, which I love. I normally hold back from early access games, but I am glad to be part of the growth and evolution of this one.

I will update this review as the game progresses. At this point, I'd say: if you want to be active part of the development, and like the style and the concept, this is a perfect time to join in. If having little play content and some balance issues bothers you, perhaps sit back, keep an eye on the forums, and see how things evolve.

Update 1: after the first game update, I can already tell that the game feels far more solid. There is more content, everything feels far more balanced, and some of the ideas discussed in the forums have been implemented. Things are looking really good!

Update 2: after the last two updates, the game has noticeably more content. It feels much deeper and more replayable, and the addition of longer missions and extra encounters also up the challenge and the need to play more strategically, rather than relying on luck. I'm very happy with all the additions so far!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a lot like the original Oregon Trail - which it should be, since it's a space adventure based on it - only without the hunting.  Sorry, folks, that was a stretch goal that wasn't met.  Some people have complained that there's no skill involved, that it all comes down to a roll of the die.  This is broadly true, but aside from that sadly missing hunting game, Oregon Trail and the more recent OMG anything is better with zombies" Organ Trail are pretty much the same way.

Will you ford the river or try to float across?  Sneak through the horde of zombies or go through guns blazing?  Rely upon your attack rating and set phasers to "shave" or go with tactics and put on encounter suits to avoid the allergy problems from these furry trading aliens?  In each situation you know something about which will be more likely to succeed
date: but can ultimately fail based on luck... it's just that Oregon Trail is more open about that fact.\n\nDespite the lack of hunting
recommended: I still think this is a good game.  You can't just min/max as another reviewer said because you won't always get the crew you want (you get a random assortment of three candidates for each slot)
hoursPlayed: you may not have your impressive attack rating as an option each encounter
voteText: and going full-on diplomacy will leave you hurting when a bravado or science crisis hits.  You instead need to try to balance your various skills
helpfulPercent: knowing that going high on a couple of things will make those challenges more likely to succeed but that it will leave other stats weak.  And while a roll of the dice may not be an extremely exciting way to play a game
votesHelpful: what you do have here is excellent writing.\n\nWhether you're trying to escape being digested in the "Oh the huge manatee" event
votesTotal: finding that your shields can't hold against savings of this magnitude when a Megamart ship flies up or playing 'pop goes the warp weasel' when you chased the little pests into your airlock
votesFunny: there is a lot that's worth reading and a few chuckles involved.  Perhaps it won't be your favorite game to return to forever
commentsCount: but it's certainly worth playing for a few hours in my opinion.  And with more content slated to be added up through and past the official release
column16: there should be plenty to do for $10."

reviewText: I enjoy this game... for the most part. I backed it on Kickstarter because the idea of a Star Trek-like Oregon Trail sounded great. Except I don't remember that game being complete chance. Nothing I do really matters. I give my ship eight points in a stat and I still fail. The game tries to use humor to make up for it's failures and it has a style that's hard to resist. But I'd be lying if I said I wasn't disappointed. Zero hunting, away missions that feel like drudgery and a pace that just leaves me clicking to get to the end keep me from recommending it. I'll still load it up from time to time, to see if I can get some enjoyment from my backing, but I don't think anyone else needs to waste their time.

reviewText:
First of all, I'm not a gamer at all, apart from watching the odd playthrough on YouTube. I had to install Steam specifically for this game. I am, however, a big Star Trek fan.

I played the demo of this game several times and watched a short (incomplete) playthrough and then decided to buy the game myself. To be honest, I don't feel like I gained much from doing so.

Here are my main issues:

- As others have said, the game is too random. You can make it less random by picking a crew that all excel in one area (e.g. diplomacy) but then you end up picking diplomacy options only as you know you will succeed, leaving you more like a trained monkey than a person making choices. I would have preferred the game to have a in-game guidebook" (e.g. Fabulons like compliments on their outfits) which would also weigh on the choices. Protocol might say to do X
date: but you are more skilled in Y and you need to decide which will give better odds. Like the game "Papers
hoursPlayed: the guidebook could also change during the game.\n\n- No over arcing plot. The demo gave you the choice of trying to finish with either the most food or fuel which could easier have been converted into plotlines (e.g. take as much food to the X planet as possible
voteText: you need to pass through 3 systems to get there). Your crew also changes from system to system which could have remained the same
votesHelpful: and also have been integrating into the plot.\n\n- The same issues occur over and over. While I don't mind each system throwing up the same set of issues each time you play
votesTotal: some of the issues occur in more than one system (and perhaps more than once within the same system
votesFunny: though I am not completely sure as it all blurs together). I would have preferred in each system had different problems.\n\n- Part of the store needs coins but there does not seem to be anyway to get coins. Perhaps I have missed something in the game
commentsCount: but this is not mentioned in the manual.\n\nIf you've not played the demo or seen it on YouTube
column16: this game is worth a play. If you have done either of those before
column17: there is no need to download to play but only to support the game designers."
column21: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game suffers from a great deal of RNG and has very little in the way of meaningful strategy. The only real decision-making in the game is choosing between a list of a few options at each node. Usually, it is advantageous to choose the option for which you have the highest corresponding stat bonus. Sometimes, it might make more sense to choose a lesser bonus if it gives a resource that you need badly. But after you hit the probabilitty drive button, you can't control the outcome. Rolling a critical failure when you have a +8 bonus, meaning that all other outcomes would be sucessful, is a horrible feeling. There's nothign you can do as a player to mitigate the outcome. It's possible to lose horribly in a given playthough and then make all the same decisions next time and be sucessful. IMO this is bad game design because it removes all agency on the part of the player. Because of the limited opportunity for player interaction, you feel as though you're along for the ride instead of actively participating. Orion trail is an initially fun distraction with a quirky style and sense of humor that  quickly wears thin as the game mechanics are laid bare.

Early Access Review

reviewText:
This game is truly for the masochists. RNGesus does not care about you. He never did.

PROS: Graphics bring me back to the good old days. The music does too. The dialogue, the pop culture references, they're all welcomed... at first.

CONS: This is why I don't believe in God. What kind of God smites you with (significant) negative consequences every single step of the way? The corny dialogue, while funny at first, rather quickly becomes just a nuisance. I lost 3 crew members because they loved their food so much that they didn't want to eat it and starved? Lost -100 fuel in transit because [insert random reason which makes absolutely no sense here]. What is supposed to be funny, I think, ultimately bites itself in the ♥♥♥. The fun factor is lost because the game literally punches you in the balls, all the time, for no fair reasons. THIS GAME ISN'T FAIR! DAMN YOU RNGESUS! I guess this is karma.

However, I won't be refunding my money. I'm going to hold onto this in the hopes that the dice will ease up on players. Because the platform is there - good things could come about. But my balls are sore, and if I play one more game my stomach's going to expel everything I ate for breakfast.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI initially started this game with optimism. I backed it on kickstarter and I was very excited about it. When early access came out for 9.99 I was a little surprised because that's half of what I paid on kickstarter but that okay, kickstarter isn't about getting a good deal it's about helping game devs get their games out. Then I played the first mission and at first thought it was kind of quirky but fun and completed the mission. The stat system seemed to balance the options and give me a sense of picking a team that is good a few things to increase my chances of success. Then I played the second mission and decided to try the opposite and stack one stat. I never choose that stat in my dialog options. I killed all of the crew and all but one of the officers but still won the level. At this point I feel like I could pick any four officers and random click my way through and I still would win. I wonder if it is even possible not to win? One reason I bought this game was because I am a fan of the Organ Trail. It is not even close to that game in it's current state. This game needs to be increased in difficulty and at the same time needs a way buy/sell/trade resources to increase the fun and make me want to replay it. There should be some kind of hunt for food mechanic and there needs to be a town mechanic. The music could use some work too. I feel like it just keeps recycling the same song maybe because I beat the game so quickly I was unable to listen to all of the music. Maybe the music could be set to random instead of the same opening song playing every time. The food and fuel aspects really need polish. One play though I lost half of my initial food on the first encounter. I'll try it again after an update but right now not very fun.

reviewText:
Reviewing the game is a bit difficult because it lends itself to two different theories on what playing it actually is.

If you consider the game to be about getting from point A to point B for each stage (which is true), then it's INSANELY difficult.  A sensible player would choose never to interact with ANYTHING, because doing anything except choosing the shortest path and refusing to do anything optional saps resources you can't afford to lose.  Trouble is, you don't have enough of those resources in the first place.  Not even close.  So you HAVE to gamble to win.  But this works out about as well as it would in real life: buying lottery tickets to make rent rarely ends well.  So the game is HARD.

On the other hand, a perfectly sensible take on what makes this a game is that you're watching the comic misadventures of a Star Trek homage/parody.  Viewed that way, watching endless abusive-but-funny terrible things happen to your crew is the whole point.  You want the ♥♥♥♥ to hit the fan just to see exactly how it'll splatter.  Casually sailing through all the levels would be silly and boring.

This makes for an odd mix.  You die constantly, which is... not ideal.  But if you get into the spirit of that, it's fun again.

It's hard to say if this is intentional or not, but the sweet spot is easily hit by rampant cheating using a memory editor.  You can usually find two of the resources in just two scans, and the other two aren't much harder, should they ever pose a real threat of running out.  Once you have the power to simply undo the game's savage punishments for exploring, you're free to relax and goof off.  Which, honestly, feels like exactly what the game was designed to be about in the first place.

It's also important to note that I'm reviewing an early version of this game.  There's already talk of updating it to be easier coming from the developers.  One way I'd personally like to see them do this is by opening up your character stats to casual mods in config files, like how the Political Machine" games do it.  That way
date: players could have fun by tailoring difficulty to their own taste.  Want to make it easy to heroically breeze through all the scenarios?  Ramp up those stats!  Want to laugh at pathetic foibles?  Use
voteText: just use the original settings.\n\nIn short
helpfulPercent: the game is fun!  And the references are solid!  But you should be prepared to cheat like you have never cheated before if the idea of constant

reviewText:
Full disclosure, I backed Orion Trail on Kickstarter and if you play the game, you have a chance of running into me as one of the villians. If that is just too much bias for you, you might want to find something else to read!

Orion Trail is Star Trek meets the Oregon Trail game with a slight detour provided by Monty Python.  The premise is simple enough; select a crew from the choices given (each crew member has different skill sets) then set out across space to encounter a rather ecelctic mix and use your skills to adapt, improvise and overcome. Or die trying. The puns are non stop, the encounters are full of BEMs (I might be showing my age here)  and you roll the digital dice (called the improbability drive which might have been stolen from some English writeer) and take your result in true RNG fashion. If things work out well, you gain some fuel or food or crew, if not, well, you might lose out! Your odds of a favorable solution are based on the skills you have and how many points you have in the skill you choose to bet on.  Its fun, silly and at times, a little repetitious but for a small game done on a tight budget, it came out very well.

Is Orion Trail perfect? No. I find it to be too heavy on food and fuel optimization. I can usually keep my shields and crew up to snuff. Some of the fun might be too inside for many; many of the characters are based on Kickstarter backers. However, is Orion Trail good clean entertainment? I think so. I like how I can play a mission in a few minutes and either be lauded as a great captain or be shown the door and a view of my tombstone (space dysentry anyone?)  There are nods to several pop culture genres here. Have some fun, try the game and see if you have what it takes to be a Galaxy Force captain or just another tomb in space! Oh, and if you run into me, I seem to be an easy grader. I gambled on taking the test last time and got a B-. I would have given myself a C.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first Kickstarter project I have ever contributed to as well as the first Early Access Game I have ever bought. I recommended it before, but now that it seems it is out of Early Access, I just can't recommend it anymore. It feels way too random. There just doesn't seem to be enough game here. You pick you captain and your officers, and you even get to rename them if you want. But the rest of the game is choosing which path to take and which stat (Attack, Science, Diplomacy, Bravado, etc.) that you are going to use to tackle the random events that crop up. After that it's all dice-rolling where the RNG feels like it, more often that not, works against you. And even now that Achievements have been activated, it doesn't really feel like any sort of actual achievement to get them. It seems like, if you just have enough playthroughs of the game, you'll get all of the achievements and nothing about your choices and skill will change that.

As for what I like about the game, there is the concept, which is basically Oregon Trail In Space." I also like the visual style of the game; I am generally tired of all the indie games these days with their retro-pixelated graphics
date: but in this game I think it adds real charm.\n\nPeople have referred to FTL when talking about this game
recommended: but the graphics and the sense of humor bring to my mind the old Space Quest series by the Two Guys from Andromeda. Also
hoursPlayed: there is so much depth of gameplay in FTL that it makes this game seem like a computerized Choose Your Own Adventure book.\n\nI can honestly say that I have had more fun playing an implementation of the original Oregon Trail on my crappy 5 year old phone than I have had with this game. It's too bad because I had high hopes for Orion Trail."

reviewText:
Cool looking game, nice retro sounds and look. Some nice comedy.
...But so random. After a series of wierd successes where I still lost more than I gained, I eventually lost all my crew and am left with the 4 'main characters' of my run. So with one guy I go on an away mission, the one guy gets a critical success...which kills him. So I have 3 crew. I then get a random encounter that some of my crew became cyborgs and need fuel, I'm locked out of the option to try to not give them fuel because I don't have any crew to lose, so I lose all my fuel. So I activate SOS and wait to be rescued, my rescuer demands some of my hull for fuel, I only have 1 hull so my only option is get fuel so I can immediately blow up and lose the game.

I know that's random chance stacking up to make a wierd story, which should be fun, except that I rarely had a choice in any of those situations and when I did have a choice it randomly decided to make things worse wether I won or lost.

Is the game interesting to watch, a bit. Is it fun to play, only if you think clicking through menus with a veneer of choice/tactics/interactiveness is fun. I really wanted a fun choose your own space adventure, Orion Trail is so not what I was hoping for. I'd probably have fun if they just made a story mode, where I could just role play the story my crew is having and be able to enjoy the game at my own pace, without the random chance ruining the experience for no logical reason.

Succumb to the chaos of the Probability Drive"

reviewText:
(Re-edited this review to avoid comparisions with the games that inspired this, comments related to the original review have been removed)

(Edited again as balancing patch fixed some of my issues with the game. I now recommend this game though only if you enjoy the humour and slot machines)

A lot of love went into creating this game, with it's nice artwork, and humour spread throughout which is why I originally backed this game on Kickstarter. However dispite the funny dialog and nice artwork I did not find the game enjoyable. The game plays out as a series events where you make decisions that all end with what is basically a slot machine, this results in a game where finishing a playthrough is based mostly on random chance.

Right from the outset the game inadvertently teaches players not to make decisions on what would you do, but rather pick the decision that will give the best odds at the next slot machine meaning the decision isn't really a decision at all, the choice is taken away from you. This also means some players stop caring about reading the dialog as they no longer have any real choice as to how the event will play out and the dialog is one of the strongest elements of the game.

With the latest patches winning a playthrough no longer feels like the grind through a random generator and now I can enjoy the humour and style of the game much more. It is and always will remain a simplified slot machine game in fancy clothing, so if the funny scripts and the winning and losing at slot machines are not something you enjoy then you'll probably want to give this game a miss.

reviewText:
While Orion Trail can be frustrating in regards to the difficulty of the “Probability Drive” it’s still quite worth playing just for the humor alone. There are plenty of nods not just to Oregon Trail (Space Dysentery anyone?) and Star Trek (redshirts galore) but also other pop culture references. Including a dance-off with Michael Jackson zombies and a trip to a Willie Wonka inspired planet. Did I mention Space Dysentery? Sure, it gets repetitive at times, especially if you keep encountering the same things, but even so the quest to make it to Orion is just too damn addictive. Now if you’ll excuse me I have to deal with my nemesis Baxxstar.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

((Updated as game is updated!))

4.5/5 Stars, rating based on game QUALITY not QUANTITY, unlike some people...

Knowing that the game is based strongly on elements the designers enjoyed from games like FTL and Oregan Trail helped me know what to expect (Kickstarter backer), but I admit that I was still pleasently surprised. While I have not found the game difficult to beat" as far as individual missions go
date: I do admit that I find it difficult to actually keep more than just the captain alive! So if you are looking for something ridiculously hard
recommended: this isnt it. If you are looking for a choice based
voteText: tongue and cheek
helpfulPercent: slap stick sense of humor riddled game that sets you up to fail rather than win
votesHelpful: this is the way to go.\n\nThe animations give a good sense of the characters (usually silly)
votesTotal: the randomness of events helps keeps things fresh every time
votesFunny: and the completely random little additions and deductions on stats based on your gameplay help even more.\n\nI would also like to add
commentsCount: that as a board gamer and ex-D&D splunker
column16: I find the ability to see your ability modifiers affect your chances
column18: to be a wonderful mechanic. It's a small thing
column19: but I find it helps the occasionally 'slow' aspects of choice desicion to be rendered kind of fun!\n\nCan't wait for the next update!"

reviewText:
Orion trail is cute but a little too mindless slot machine.
Was hoping for something more FTL like but with more character.
It definitely has the character just not enough game for my tastes.
There are decisions but the decisions are no more difficult than the decisions in tic-tac-toe

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is not a good game if you can even call it a game seeing you just press a key and hope for the best. There is no way to get more stuff since you always loose stuff when you get some... so you will always go to zero no matter what and all you can do is hope you get lucky.

Same effect:
Toss a coin 10 times and hope its heads for 9 times in a row or you've lost. Each time its heads look at a nice picture if its not look at an ugly picture instead. Have fun!

reviewText: A stupid (and clumsy) FTL rip-off. Not even worth $1 as a mobile game. Take note that most reviewers have less than an hours game time; it can't even hold your attention for that - I bet they are getting hammered by Steam's refund policy - but so they should!
voteText: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay, so loads of people are complaining about the RNG. That's not why you play this game. The main attraction is the incredible, witty, extremely hilarious writing. You just need to know why you're playing it, and it breaks down like this:

Every encounter has five ways to approach it: Attack, Tactics, Diplomacy, Science, and Bravado.
Every approach has four possible outcomes: Success, Fail, Critical Success, Critical Fail.

So there are 20 outcomes to each encounter, and there are hundreds of encounters. So far, almost every single line has had me in stitches. So this is what the game is.

The game is you trying to discover each line of dialogue. I hope I have made this decision easier for you!

(seriously, I haven't played a game this funny in years)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game has its pros and it's cons, lets start out with the pros

Pros:
-Great Art Style And Animations

-Great Humor

-Good Stats System


Cons:
-Mostly Luck Based

-No Minigames (Hunting and ETC)

-All levels seem mostly the same

Overall I played this and had alot of fun, although I don't think i'll play this much more again, but I'm sure there is other people out there who will enjoy this more. Since I got the game for free and I got to meet the devs of this game this review may be a bit biased but even without that if you're willing to pay 10 dollars then I think most people will enjoy this game.



7/10 : Average

-AkaJacob
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Fun way to kill some time, and lots of redshirts. I like the writing, too. I do wish that the spinner for success/fail would not be so time consuming (maybe I missed a way to skip it). Pretty happy with it overall.
